module.p: bi be is the predicative simple verb.

section.p:
The principal parts of bi are –
tha / (bh)eil – present independent/dependent – is, are, am
bidh / bi – future independent/dependent – will be
bha / robh – past independent/dependent – was, were
bhiodh / biodh – conditional independent/dependent – would be
bith – verbal noun – being

section.p:
bi is used in subject-predicate constructions –
Tha an cù dubh.
The dog is black. td. 6
An robh an cat aig an teine?
Was the cat is by the fire? td. 6 [adapted]
Chan eil Màiri ag obair.
Mary is not working. td. 6 [adapted]
The subject of bi can be a noun or a pronoun.

Some examples –
proper nouns –
Bha Màiri sgìth.
Mary was tired. td. 7 [adapted]
Nach eil Calum anns an achadh?
Isn’t Malcolm in the field? td. 11
common nouns –
animate –
An robh an cat bàn?
Was the cat white? td. 6 [adapted]
Tha an cù dubh aig an dorus.
The black dog is at the door. td. 9
Tha an duine anns a’ bhàta.
The man is in the boat. td. 17
inanimate –
Bha an dorus mór.
The door was big. td. 6 [adapted]
Chan eil falt dubh air Calum.
Calum does not have black hair. td. 9 [adapted]
Tha am bàta air a’ chladach.
The boat is on the shore. td. 17
A bheil uisge anns a’ choire? Tha.
Is there water in the kettle? Yes, there is. td. 120
abstract –
Tha teas anns an teine.
There is heat in the fire. td. 6
pronouns –
personal pronouns –
Tha Màiri bhàn anns an achadh an diugh agus tha i ag obair gu trang.
Fair-headed Mary is in the field today and she is working busily. td. 9
An robh thu sgìth?
Were you tired? td. 11 [adapted]
non-referential third person singular pronouns –
Chan eil e fuar an diugh.
It is not cold today. td. 11
demonstrative pronouns –
Cha robh sin math.
That was not good. td. 15 [adapted]
Tha seo teth.
This (one) is hot. td. 15
examples with agus and –
Tha Màiri agus Calum ag obair.
Mary and Malcolm are working. td. 7

The predicate of bi can be an adjective or a (static) preposition –
Bha Calum sgìth.
Malcolm was tired. td. 7 [adapted]
Nach eil an cù aig an dorus?
Isn’t the dog is at the door? td. 6 [adapted]
The predicate of bi can be an (uninflected) adjective.

Some examples –
Bha an cù dubh ach bha an cat bàn.
The dog was black but the cat was white. td. 6 [adapted]
Chan eil Màiri agus Calum trang an diugh.
Mary and Malcolm are not busy today. td. 7 [adapted]
An robh thu sgìth?
Were you tired? td. 11 [adapted]
Tha e fuar an diugh.
It is cold today. td. 7
The predicate of bi can be a (static) preposition.

Some examples –
Tha sibh aig an teine.
You are at the fire. td. 9 [226]
Nach robh Calum anns an achadh?
Wasn’t Malcolm in the field? td. 11
A bheil an cù aig an dorus?
Is the dog at the door? td. 11
Bha teas anns an teine.
There was heat in the fire. td. 6
Tha am bàta air a’ chladach.
The boat is on the shore. td. 17
More specifically, the predicate of bi can be the progressive particle ag, followed by a verbal noun.

Some examples –
Tha Màiri agus Calum ag obair anns an achadh an diugh.
Mary and Malcolm are working in the field today. td. 6–7
Dé tha Seumas a’ dèanamh an diugh?
What is James doing today? td. 14
An robh a’ chaileag a’ cluich air an làr?
Was the girl playing on the floor? td. 15 [adapted]
An robh Calum ag iasgach air an loch an dé? Bha.
Was Malcolm fishing on the lake yesterday? Yes, he was. td. 20
The predicate of bi can be an adverb.

Some examples –
Càit a bheil an cù? Tha e còmhla ri Calum.
Where is the dog? It is with Calum. td. 19–20

bi can take more than one predicate, without needing an explicit conjunction agus and –
Tha Màiri beag bàn.
Mary is small and fair-haired. td. 8
Bha iad fuar ag obair anns an achadh an dé.
They were cold working in the field yesterday. td. 7 [adapted]
Nach eil sibh trang ag obair.
Weren’t you busy working? td. 9 [adapted]

But see also –
Tha Màiri agus Calum fliuch agus fuar.
Mary and Malcolm are wet and cold. td. 7 [226]
bi can occur with one or more modifiers.

Examples with temporal modifiers –
Tha iad fuar ag obair anns an achadh an diugh.
They are tired working in the field today. td. 7
Cha robh e fuar an dé.
It was not cold today. td. 11 [adapted]

Examples with locative modifiers –
Tha iad fuar anns an achadh an diugh.
They are cold in the field today. td. 9

Examples with comitative modifiers –
Tha an duine anns a’ mhonadh leis a’ chù.
The man is on the moor with the dog. td. 19
An independent form of bi can be used as a sentential root.

Some present tense examples –
Tha an cù dubh.
The dog is black. td. 6
Tha an gille aig an dorus.
The boy is at the door. td. 15

Some past tense examples –
Bha Màiri trang.
Mary was busy. td. 16
Bha Calum agus Màiri ag obair.
Malcolm and Mary were working. td. 16
An independent form of bi can be used as the head of a conjunct with sentential agus and or ach but.

Some examples –
Tha Màiri bhàn anns an achadh an diugh agus tha i ag obair gu trang.
Fair-headed Mary is in the field today and she is working busily. td. 9
Tha an gille mór, ach tha a’ chaileag beag.
The boy is big, but the girl is small. td. 15
A dependent form of bi can be used as the complement of one of the verb particles cha, an or nach.

module.p: chan eil is not is the negative form of tha.

Some examples –
Chan eil e fuar an diugh.
It is not cold today. td. 11
Chan eil an seòmar seo blàth?
This room is not warm. td. 14
Chan eil Seònaid anns an achadh còmhla ri Seumas.
Janet is not in the field along with James. td. 14
cha robh was not is the negative form of bha.

Some examples –
Cha robh mi anns an taigh.
I was not at home. td. 17
a bheil is the interrogative form of tha.

Some examples –
A bheil an cù aig an dorus? Tha.
Is the dog at the door? Yes, it is. td. 11
A bheil sibh ag obair? Chan eil.
Are you working? No, I’m not. td. 13
A bheil an t-uisge ann? Tha gu dearbh.
Is it raining. Yes, indeed. td. 14 [adapted]

Some examples –
Càit a bheil an cat bàn an-diugh? Tha e anns an taigh còmhla ri Seònaid.
Where is the white cat today? It is in the house along with Janet. td. 14
Càit a bheil a’ chaileag a’ cluich? Tha i a’ cluich air an làr.
Where is the girl playing? She is playing on the floor. td. 15
Càit a bheil Màiri an diugh? Tha i anns a’ bhaile.
Where is Mary today? She is in the town. td. 20
Càit a bheil thu a’ fuireach? Tha mi a’ fuireach anns a’ chlachan.
Where do you live? I live in the village. td. 20
an robh is the interrogative form of bha.

Some examples –
An robh Màiri trang?
Was Mary busy? td. 16
An robh Calum agus Seònaid ag obair?
Were Malcolm and Janet working? td. 16 [adapted]
An robh thu sgìth? Bha.
Were you tired? Yes, I was. td. 16
An robh sibh anns an achadh an diugh? Cha robh.
Were you in the field today? No, we weren’t. td. 16
An robh Calum ag iasgach air an loch an dé? Bha.
Was Malcolm fishing on the lake yesterday? Yes, he was. td. 20

Some examples –
Càit an robh an cat bàn?
Where was the white cat? made up
nach eil is the negative form of a bheil, and the interrogative form of chan eil.

Some examples –
Nach eil Calum anns an achadh? Chan eil.
Isn’t Malcolm in the field? No, he isn’t. td. 11
Nach eil Seumas ag obair an diugh? Tha.
Isn’t James working today? Yes, he is. td. 14
Nach eil thu sgìth? Tha, tha mi glé sgìth.
Aren’t you tired. Yes, I am very tired. td. 14
nach robh is the negative form of an robh, and the interrogative form of cha robh.

Some examples –
Nach robh Màiri trang? Bha.
Wasn’t Mary busy? Yes, she was. td. 17

Some examples –
Dé tha Seònaid a’ dèanamh anns an taigh? Tha i a’ cluich air an làr.
What is Janet doing in the house? She is playing on the floor. td. 14
Dé tha air an teine? Tha gual air an teine.
What is on the fire? There is coal on the fire. td. 14

Some examples –
Có tha a’ cluich air an làr? The girl.
Who is playing on the floor? A’ chaileag. td. 15
Có bha ag iasgach air an loch? Bha Calum.
Who was fishing on the lake? Calum was. td. 20

Some examples –
Ciamar a tha sibh? Tha mi gu math, tapadh leibh.
How are you? I am well, thank you. td. 15

section.p: The Gaelic verb bi is the fusion of at least three different Old Gaelic verbs.

module.p: The ‘substantive verb’ at·tá be belongs to the H1 conjugation.

The conjugated present tense absolute forms are (Stifter: 133) –
at·táu / at·tó I am, at·taí thou art, at·tá [(s)he/it] is, at·taaṁ we are, at·taiḋ you are, at·taaṭ [they] are

Some examples –
intransitive (existence) –
at·tá in Coimmdiu
There is the Lord; The Lord exists. td. 136
with a preposition –
physical location –
at·taaṁ i Finnbain indossa
We are now in Vienna. td. 136
condition –
at·tó i mo ṡuiḋiu ar bélaiḃ ríṁairi
I am sat in front of the computer. td. 136
at·tó i ngalur
I am ill. td. 136
with a predicative adjective in VSO order –
at·taaṭ mesai Dé nephchomtetarrachti amal abis
The judgments of God are incomprehensible like an abyss. [Ml. 55d11] td. 136
ro·bátar [?] ind liss dúntai
The ramparts were closed. [IB 1] td. 136

The conjugated present tense conjunct forms are (Stifter: 136) –
·táu / ·tó I am, ·taí thou art, ·tá [(s)he/it] is, ·taaṁ we are, ·taiḋ you are, ·taaṭ [they] are

However, these conjunct forms are only used in very limited contexts –
after an infixed dative pronoun nín·tá there is not to us, we don’t have
after a preposition + relative particle lasa·tá with whom is

·fil is a defective third person singular conjunct verb form (derived from an imperative meaning see!), which provides present tense conjunct forms for at·tá, with the subject represented by an infixed pronoun.

Negative conjugated forms (Stifter: 137) –
ním·ḟil I am not, níṭ·ḟil thou art not, ní·fil he is not, nís·fil she is not, ní·ḟil it is not, nínn·fil we are not, níḃ·fil you are not, nís·fil they are not

Interrogative examples –
in·f̣il in mnaí [acc] sund? nís·fil
Is the woman here? No, she isn’t. td. 136
in·f̣il inna echu [acc] arind achud? nís·fil
Are the horses on the pasture? No, they aren’t. td. 136
The verb biiḋ be usually belongs to the H2 conjugation.

The conjugated present tense absolute forms are (Stifter: 133) –
bíuu I am usually, bii thou art usually, biiḋ [(s)he/it] is usually, bímmi we are usually, ? you are usually, biiṭ they are usually

The conjugated present tense conjunct forms are (Stifter: 179) –
? I am usually, ? thou art usually, ·bí [(s)he/it] is usually, ·bíaṁ we are usually, ? you are usually, ·bíaṭ they are usually
